CEN 3078 – Computer Security
Module 2 – Application and Network Attacks – Part 2

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Module 2 Part 2 Overview
• TCP and session attacks
• Cookie, session, and token abuse
• Web application attacks
• DoS and DDoS techniques
• Detection and mitigation strategies

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
TCP Basics for Attackers and Defenders
• Three-way handshake: SYN → SYN-ACK → ACK
• Sequence and acknowledgment numbers
• Connection state (LISTEN, SYN-RECEIVED, ESTABLISHED)
• Why it matters: spoofing, flooding, and hijacking rely on these mechanics

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
SYN Flood Attack
• Sends large volumes of SYN packets with bogus sources
• Server allocates half-open state; backlog fills
• Legitimate clients starve → denial of service
• Defenses: SYN cookies, backlog tuning, rate limits, filtering, CDN scrubbing

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
TCP Reset and Session Desynchronization
• Inject forged RST packets to tear down connections
• Guessable sequence windows enable resets
• Impacts long-lived flows (BGP, streaming)
• Mitigations: TCP authentication options, encryption, tighter RST checks

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
TCP Session Hijacking
• Attacker observes or predicts sequence numbers
• Injects packets to take over application stream
• Often combined with ARP spoofing or on-path placement
• Defenses: TLS, VPNs, random ISNs, switch port security, DHCP snooping

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Name and Address Spoofing
• ARP spoofing: poison cache to intercept traffic on LANs
• DNS poisoning: inject false records → redirect domains
• IP spoofing: falsify source address for reflection and evasion
• Countermeasures: dynamic ARP inspection, DNSSEC, uRPF, egress filtering

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Cookies, Sessions, and Tokens
• Cookies persist state across stateless HTTP
• Session identifiers map to server-side state
• Tokens (including JSON Web Tokens) carry claims
• Risks: theft, fixation, weak entropy, improper scopes and expiry

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Cookie and Session Attacks
• Session fixation: force victim to use attacker’s ID
• Session hijacking: steal ID via XSS, sniffing, malware
• Insecure attributes: missing HttpOnly, Secure, SameSite
• Defenses: rotate IDs on login, strong attributes, short TTL, server-side revocation lists

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Web Injection Attacks
• SQL injection: untrusted input in queries
• Command injection: shell or interpreter abuse
• Template injection and deserialization flaws
• Prevention: parameterized queries, allowlists, input normalization, safe APIs

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Cross-Site Scripting and Request Forgery
• XSS: injects script into victim’s browser context
• CSRF: tricks browser into sending authenticated action
• Protections: output encoding, CSP, input validation, SameSite cookies, CSRF tokens, double-submit patterns

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Authentication and Authorization Pitfalls
• Weak password storage (plain, md5)
• Missing MFA, credential stuffing exposures
• Broken access control and IDOR
• Best practices: salted adaptive hashing, MFA, least privilege, deny by default, comprehensive authorization checks on every request

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Denial-of-Service (DoS) and Distributed DoS (DDoS)
• Volumetric: saturate bandwidth (UDP floods, amplification)
• Protocol: exhaust state (SYN floods, fragmented packets)
• Application: expensive requests (HTTP, login brute force)
• Mitigation: rate limits, caching, WAF rules, anycast CDNs, upstream scrubbing centers

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Reflection and Amplification Attacks
• Spoofed source to reflect traffic at victim
• Amplifiers: DNS, NTP, memcached, CLDAP
• Small requests → massive responses
• Defenses: BCP 38 egress filtering, rate-limit amplifiers, close open resolvers, use anycast and autoscaling at edge

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Detection and Monitoring
• IDS and IPS signatures for known patterns
• Anomaly detection on baselines and flows
• Web and API telemetry: status codes, latencies, error spikes
• Centralized logging and SIEM correlation with alert tuning to reduce noise

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Response and Hardening Playbook
• Prepare: inventories, runbooks, contacts, backups
• Identify and contain: block indicators, isolate segments
• Eradicate and recover: patch, rotate credentials, restore
• Improve: post-incident review, control gaps, tabletop exercises

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Threat Intelligence and Attribution
• Aggregates IoCs from multiple incidents
• Enables proactive blocking and trend awareness
• Attribution analyzes TTPs (tactics, techniques, procedures)
• Sources: ISACs, MISP, commercial and open feeds

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Incident Lifecycle Model
1. Preparation
2. Detection and Analysis
3. Containment, Eradication, Recovery
4. Post-Incident Activity
Aligns with NIST SP 800-61 Rev. 2 guidance for IR teams.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Data Breach Examples
• Equifax 2017 – unpatched Apache Struts vuln → PII leak
• Target 2013 – HVAC vendor credentials → POS malware
• Colonial Pipeline 2021 – ransomware → fuel supply disruption
Lesson: patching, vendor security, and segmentation are critical.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Supply Chain Attacks
• Target dependencies or updates to compromise many
• Examples: SolarWinds, CCleaner, npm typosquatting
• Mitigation: verify signatures, SBOMs, least-privilege build systems, monitor artifact integrity

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Zero-Day Exploits
• Previously unknown vulnerabilities with no patch
• Valuable to both defenders and attackers
• Defenses: virtual patching, behavioral detection, defense-in-depth, vulnerability disclosure programs

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Browser and Client-Side Attacks
• Exploit browser plugins, extensions, or outdated code
• Drive-by downloads and malvertising
• Sandbox bypass and privilege escalation
• Mitigation: patch browsers, limit plugins, enable sandboxing and application whitelisting

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Mobile Threats
• Malicious apps or SDKs harvest data
• Jailbreak/root exploits remove controls
• Unsecured Wi-Fi and Bluetooth attacks
• Defenses: MDM, app-store vetting, VPN usage, user permissions review

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
IoT Vulnerabilities
• Default credentials and insecure firmware
• Lack of updates and logging
• Physical access risks and exposed APIs
• Mitigation: network segmentation, firmware signing, device inventory management

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Cloud Security Risks
• Misconfigured storage buckets and IAM roles
• Shared responsibility confusion
• Insecure APIs and keys in code repos
• Solutions: CSPM, least privilege, cloud WAF, secrets management, continuous auditing

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Email Security Threats
• Phishing, spear-phishing, business email compromise
• Malicious attachments and links
• Spoofed domains and look-alike addresses
• Countermeasures: SPF, DKIM, DMARC, sandbox analysis, security awareness training

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Insider Threats
• Malicious or negligent employees
• Data exfiltration via USB, email, cloud sync
• Privilege misuse and policy violations
• Mitigation: least privilege, monitoring, user behavior analytics, training and deterrence

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Security Frameworks and Controls
• NIST CSF, ISO 27001, CIS Controls
• Provide structured approach to risk management
• Controls: Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover
• Use as benchmarks for policy and compliance programs

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Legal and Ethical Considerations
• GDPR, HIPAA, PCI-DSS impact incident handling
• Obligations for notification and data minimization
• Ethics in disclosure and research
• Balance transparency with responsible security practice

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Emerging Threats
• AI-driven phishing and deepfakes
• Quantum impact on cryptography
• Critical infrastructure and ICS vulnerabilities
• 5G and edge computing security gaps
• Continuous adaptation required for defense

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 2.pptx

document:
Summary
• TCP, session, and web attacks exploit protocol and logic flaws
• Defenses require layered controls and vigilant monitoring
• Incident response and frameworks guide resilience
• Stay current with threat intel and secure development lifecycles
